docs.title: itksn
docs.text:
CI/CD Docs Package Meta

itksn is a tool used to parse (and build) serial numbers for the ATLAS ITk project documented at itk.docs.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Multiple components supported
  • Easy to contribute and extend
  • Usable CLI

docs.title: License
docs.text: itksn is distributed under the terms of the BSD-3 license.

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Documentation for specific MAJOR.MINOR versions can be chosen by using the dropdown on the top of every page. The dev version reflects changes that have not yet been released.

Also, desktop readers can use special keyboard shortcuts:

Keys Action
  • , (comma)
  • p
Navigate to the "previous" page
  • . (period)
  • n
Navigate to the "next" page
  • /
  • s
Display the search modal

docs.title: Pixel FE Chip Name to Serial Number
docs.text:
from itksn.core import SerialNumberStruct

serialNumber = SerialNumberStruct.build(
    dict(
        atlas_project="atlas_detector",
        system_code="phaseII_upgrade",
        project_code="pixel_general",
        subproject_code="FE_chip",
        identifier=str(0x130D7).zfill(7).encode("utf-8"),  # (1)!
    )
)
assert serialNumber == b"20UPGFC0078039"  # (2)!
  1. One passes in the integer representation of the chip name which is treated as an integer in python, which we convert to a string and fill with leading zeros using str.zfill and then encode as bytes (for the underlying construct object to build out.
  2. The result of this is the serial number as bytes, not a string. One can decode as normal.

docs.title: pip
docs.text:
itksn is available on PyPI and can be installed with pip.

pip install itksn

Warning

This method modifies the Python environment in which you choose to install. Consider instead using pipx or virtual environments to avoid dependency conflicts.

docs.title: pipx
docs.text:
pipx allows for the global installation of Python applications in isolated environments.

pipx install itksn

docs.title: virtual environment
docs.text:
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
python -m pip install itksn

docs.title: Conda
docs.text:
See the feedstock for more details.

conda install -c conda-forge itksn

or with mamba:

mamba install itksn

Warning

This method modifies the Conda environment in which you choose to install. Consider instead using pipx or condax to avoid dependency conflicts.

docs.title: itksn
docs.text:
Manage top-level options

Usage:

itksn [OPTIONS] COMMAND [ARGS]...

Options:

  --version             Print the current version.
  --install-completion  Install completion for the current shell.
  --show-completion     Show completion for the current shell, to copy it or
                        customize the installation.
  --help                Show this message and exit.

docs.title: itksn parse
docs.text:
Parse the provided serial number.

Usage:

itksn parse [OPTIONS] SERIALNUMBER

Options:

  SERIALNUMBER  [required]
  --help        Show this message and exit.

docs.title: Potpourri
docs.text:
Q: Why is the FAQ empty?

A: We're still working on fleshing it out. Check back soon. In the meantime, open a discussion or file an issue.

docs.title: new staticmethod
docs.text:
new(bytevalue: bytes, stringvalue: str) -> EnumByteString

Create EnumByteString object as a class constructor

Source code in src/itksn/common.py 
@staticmethod
def new(bytevalue: bytes, stringvalue: str) -> EnumByteString:
    """
    Create EnumByteString object as a class constructor
    """
    ret = EnumByteString(stringvalue)
    ret.bytevalue = bytevalue
    return ret

docs.title: EnumStr
docs.text:
EnumStr(subcon: Construct[bytes, bytes], **mapping: bytes)

Bases: TheAdapter

This is exactly the same as construct.Enum, but supports byte subcons.

Source code in src/itksn/common.py 
def __init__(self: Self, subcon: Construct[bytes, bytes], **mapping: bytes) -> None:
    super().__init__(subcon)
    self.encmapping: dict[str, bytes] = {
        EnumByteString.new(v, k): v for k, v in mapping.items()
    }
    self.decmapping: dict[bytes, EnumByteString] = {
        v: EnumByteString.new(v, k) for k, v in mapping.items()
    }
    self.ksymapping: dict[bytes, str] = {v: k for k, v in mapping.items()}
